contentrichtext.text: {{Use Indian English|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox cricketer | name = Vijay Manjrekar | image = | caption = | batting = Right-hand bat | bowling = Right-arm offbreak | columns = 2 | column1 = [[Test cricket|Tests]] | matches1 = 55 | runs1 = 3208 | bat avg1 = 39.12 | 100s/50s1 = 7/15 | top score1 = 189* | deliveries1 = 204 | wickets1 = 1 | bowl avg1 = 44.00 | fivefor1 = - | tenfor1 = - | best bowling1 = 1/16 | catches/stumpings1= 19/2 | column2 = [[First-class cricket|First-class]] | matches2 = 198 | runs2 = 12832 | bat avg2 = 49.92 | 100s/50s2 = 38/56 | top score2 = 283 | deliveries2 = 1411 | wickets2 = 20 | bowl avg2 = 32.85 | fivefor2 = - | tenfor2 = - | best bowling2 = 4/21 | catches/stumpings2= 72/6 | international = true | country = Indian | testdebutfor = | testdebutagainst = | testdebutdate = 30 December | testdebutyear = 1951 | lasttestdate = 27 February | lasttestfor = | lasttestagainst = | lasttestyear = 1965 | source = http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/ci/content/player/30936.html | date = | year = }} '''Vijay Laxman Manjrekar''' {{audio|Vijay_Manjrekar.ogg|pronunciation}} (26 September 1931 in [[Mumbai]] â€“ 18 October 1983 in [[Madras]]) is a former [[Indian cricket team|Indian cricketer]] who played 55 Tests. A small man, he was a fine cutter and hooker of the ball. He was the father of [[Sanjay Manjrekar]]. His debut came against [[England cricket team|England]] at [[Eden Gardens|Calcutta]] in 1951, making a composed 48. He scored his first Test hundred in June 1952 against England at [[Headingley Stadium|Headingley]] making 133. It was his first Test in England and he was just 20 at the time. When he came in to bat his side was in trouble at 3/42 and faced a formidable lineup of bowlers in [[Fred Trueman|Trueman]], [[Alec Bedser|Bedser]] and [[Jim Laker|Laker]]. He put on 222 with [[Vijay Hazare|Hazare]] in an innings that showed he would be a force to be reckoned with in the future. He would however fail to fulfill his early promise and faced problems with his weight and footwork. He would eventually finish with a Test average of 39, a disappointment for a man capable of averaging well into the 40's. His finest series came against England in India 1961-62 when he made 586 runs @ 83.71. This included the highest score of his 7 centuries, with 189 at [[Feroz Shah Kotla|Delhi]]. Another notable performance was in 1964-65 where his innings of 59 and 39 helped India to a Test victory over [[Australia cricket team|Australia]]. He scored a ton in his final Test innings, coming against [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]] at [[M. A. Chidambaram Stadium|Madras]] in February 1965. He holds the records for the most test [[Run (cricket)|runs]] scored (3,208) without hitting a single [[Boundary (cricket)|six]].<ref name="Walmsley">{{cite book|last=Walmsley|first=Keith|title=Mosts Without in Test Cricket|year=2003|publisher=Keith Walmsley Publishing Pty Ltd|location=Reading, England |isbn=0947540067|pages=457}}.</ref> Manjrekar was also an occasional [[Off spin|offspinner]] and occasional [[wicketkeeper]]. He played for 6 sides in the Ranji Trophy, representing [[Mumbai cricket team|Mumbai]], [[Bengal cricket team|Bengal]], [[Uttar Pradesh cricket team|Uttar Pradesh]], [[Rajasthan cricket team|Rajasthan]], [[Andhra Pradesh cricket team|Andhra Pradesh]], and [[Maharashtra cricket team|Maharashtra]]. He had a prolific career in the tournament, scoring 3,734 runs @ 57.44.
